did.unittitle: Virginians for Alternatives to the Death Penalty Records
did.abstract: This collection contains materials used by Virginians for Alternatives to the Death Penalty (VADP) in its efforts to end capital punishment in Virginia.
did.physloc: The materials are located onsite in the department.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Chelsea Wallace processed the 2008 accession in 2016.
Meghan Slaff processed the 2024 accession in 2025.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to this collection is unrestricted with the exception of select items noted in Series 5.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: The researcher assumes full responsibility for conforming with the laws of copyright. Whenever possible, the M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections and Archives will provide information about copyright owners and other restrictions, but the legal determination ultimately rests with the researcher. Requests for permission to publish material from this collection should be discussed with the Head of Special Collections and Archives.

This page may contain links to digital objects. Access to these images and the technical capacity to download them does not imply permission for re-use. Digital objects may be used freely for personal reference use, referred to, or linked to from other web sites. Researchers do not have permission to publish or disseminate material from these collections without permission from an archivist and/or the copyright holder. The researcher assumes full responsibility for conforming to the laws of copyright. Some materials in these collections may be protected by the U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) and/or by the copyright or neighboring-rights laws of other nations. More information about U.S. Copyright is provided by the Copyright Office. Additionally, re-use may be restricted by terms of University Libraries gift or purchase agreements, donor restrictions, privacy and publicity rights, licensing and trademarks. The Department of Special Collections and Archives is eager to hear from any copyright owners who are not properly identified so that appropriate information may be provided in the future.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Virginians for Alternatives to the Death Penalty first donated its records to the M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections & Archives in 2008. Michael E. Stone, executive director of Virginians for Alternatives to the Death Penalty, donated additional paper and digital materials in 2024.

bioghist.head: Biographical History
bioghist.p: Virginians for Alternatives to the Death Penalty was founded in 1991 under the name of Virginians for Alternatives to State Killing by a group of 13 concerned citizens. In 1994 the group adopted the name, Virginians for Alternatives to the Death Penalty (VADP). The organization sought a moratorium on the death penalty in Virginia and continued to educate the public about inconsistencies in capital punishment for three decades.

The VADP rallied against the death penalty in a number of ways, including execution vigils, non-violent protests, and lobbying. The VADP held yearly conferences that individuals could attend. Membership in the VADP was open to anyone who wished to join and was not restricted to just Virginia citizens.

The VADP worked to educate the public and legislators about the ineffectiveness of the death penalty in Virginia and Virginia's 21 day rule, a policy which prohibited trial judges from reviewing newly discovered evidence if it was presented more than three weeks after a defendant's sentencing.
On March 24, 2021, Virgina Governor Ralph Northam signed legislation abolishing the death penalty, making Virginia the 23rd state, and the first in South, to stop executions. Having built support among legislators to pass the bill, VADP achieved its 30-year objective of a moratorium on capital punishment in Virginia. Having reached this goal, knowing other allies would continue to safeguard the death penalty moratorium and waiting two years to ensure that the legislation was not quickly reinstated, the VADP board elected to close the organization in February 2024.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Virginians for Alternatives to the Death Penalty (VADP) Records cover the entirey of the history of the organization's efforts, and success, to end the death penalty in Virginia. Physical materials included in this collection document the VADP's day-to-day activities such as petitions seeking an end to capital punishment in Virginia, Virginia General Assembly legislation, case law and legal education materials, subject files, newspaper clippings, scholarly articles, VHS tapes, and banners. Digital materials, added in the 2024 accession, include images, activity and planning documents, web news articles, documents relating to regional meetings, lobbying documents, digital equivalents of administrative documents such as tax forms, materials related to board activities, fundraising documents such as grant applications, planning documents, annual reports, letters, emails, and newsletters to members and non-members, and research materials from partnership organizations.
Although the VADP was established in 1991, a number of materials dated prior to 1991 are included in the collection, acquired by the VADP for research purposes.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Collection
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into the following series:
Series 1, 2, 3, 5, 6, and 7 are arranged alphabetically while Series 4 is arranged chronologically.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Preferred citation for this material is as follows:

Identification of specific item, series, box, folder, Virginians for Alternatives to the Death Penalty Records, 1937-2023. M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections and Archives, University Libraries, University at Albany, State University of New York (hereafter referred to as the Virginians for Alternatives to the Death Penalty Records).

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: The archivist transferred four monographs: A Courageous Fool: Marie Deans and Her Struggle Against the Death Penalty by Todd C. Peppers, Closing the Slaughterhouse: The Inside Story of Death Penalty Abolition in Virginia, Railroaded: The True Stories of the First 100 People Executed in Virginia's Electric Chair and Virginia State Penitentiary: A Notorious History all by Dale Brumfield to the book division of Special Collections. They will be catalogued and included in the University Library Catalog.

controlaccess.corpname: Virginians for Alternatives to the Death Penalty

did.unittitle: Administration

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of administrative materials of Virginians for Alternatives to the Death Penalty from the history of their various establishing documents, including their previous names such as Virginians Against State Killing (VASK), to records that reflect their organizational functions such as Board Meeting materials, tax documents, financial documents, annual reports, fundraising letters, strategy documents, and award luncheons. There are also materials surrounding partnerships with other related organizations such as 8th Amendment Project as well as multiple grant applications, awards, and communications from organizations such as the Death Penalty Mobilization Fund (DPMF), The Tides Foundation, Cathedral of Sacred Heart, Church of Epiphany, Daughters of Wisdom, The Advocacy Fund, Shepard's Grant, Sisters of Bon Secours, and St. Mary's Human Concerns Endowment. A majority of the documents surrounding the succesful abolition of the death penalty in Virginia can be found here.
Please note that a majority of this series contains born-digital files.

odd.head: Content Warning
odd.p: This series may contain graphic and potentially traumatic descriptions of executions and their circumstances. The original descriptions may contain harmful language or fail to demonstrate sufficient empathy for the subjects they depict.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of case files, General Assembly, House and Senate Bills, and law journals used by Virginians for Alternatives to the Death Penalty for legal research, such as American Bar Association reports, in their efforts to bring about a moratorium on capital punishment in Virginia. A bulk of the materials relate to efforts made to stop executions for those with severe mental illness. Partnership materials, showcasing joint efforts between Murder Victims Family Members for Reconciliation (MVFMR) and VADP, are also prevelant.

Publications

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Publications include newsletters, magazines, and studies that Virginians for Alternatives to the Death Penalty used to support ongoing efforts to abolish capital punishment. Flyers and pamphlets are also included in this series.
This is the only series that does not contain any digital objects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of letters and emails sent to and from members of Virginians for Alternatives to the Death Penalty such as "Email Alerts" and "Action Alert" e-newsletters. A large portion of this series consists of letters to and from various high profile death row inmates in Virginia such as Joe Giarratano and Herbert Bassette. Also contained are press and media releases, documents surrounding the efforts of the "VADP Communications Task Force," website redesign, social media efforts and metrics, Op-Eds, VADP Annual Reports, and newspaper articles written for or about the VADP.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials related to projects and programs hosted and or attended by Virginians for Alternatives to the Death Penalty such as the National Weekend of Faith, National Coalition to Abolish the Death Penalty (NCADP) Conferences, Starving for Justice, VADP Conferences, Virginia Catholic Conference, various regional meetings, Juvenile Death Penalty Awareness Day, fasts and vigils, and coalition meetings. It also contains activity planning documents for VADP.

scopecontent.p: This series consists of petitions, including the "Moratorium 2000" petition, the "Stop Look and Listen" petitions, conservative petitions, and the Severe Mental Illness in Virginia sign-on letter for the Murder Victim Family Members.

Subject Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains a number of materials that Virginians for Alternatives to the Death Penalty researched or used to further the organization's efforts to end capital punishment in Virginia. Many materials were produced by partner organizations such as the 8th Amendment Project, Conservatives Who Oppose the Death Penalty and Conservatives Concerned about Death Penalty, Murder Victim Family Memembers, and National Coalition to Abolish the Death Penalty. Topics consist of the juvenile death penalty, lethal injection, death penalty and the catholic church social teachings, death penalty events hosted by other organizations, and national and international stances on the death penalty.
Physical formats include clippings, journal articles, VHS tapes, banners, and a customized license plate.
Digital files include images, video thumbnails and stills, presentation slides, information graphics, and web articles.

odd.head: Content Warning
odd.p: This series contains graphic and potentially traumatic descriptions of executions and their circumstances. The original descriptions may contain harmful language or fail to demonstrate sufficient empathy for the subjects they depict.
